You will not be sorry with this camera.

Reviews.Title: The Best Point and Shoot camera for less than $200!
Reviews.Author: K. Harper
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera after I started to become more interested in photography. I used to use Nikon Coolpix S4000, but I wasn't too happy about the photo quality when it comes to the very bright daylight and night time. BUT, I'm far from one of those photo techies and still in the range of beginners so I didn't want to spend too much money. After researching, this camera seems to fit the bill, as this provides good amount of zoom plus it's under $200. I'm glad to choose this camera, as this has lots of functions like many other high end, more expensive camera, if you use it in manual mode. If you use it complete auto mode, it does adjust everything for you according to the surroundings. It takes fabulous pictures with sharp focus even from the car that is driving 75 mile/hr. The zoom is way enough for a beginner like me, and this camera also works great for someone like my husband who is more advanced photographer. In fact, he is quite amazed how much he can adjust the setting easily and takes great pictures. He even started to think about getting a Canon camera instead of Nikon, which he used to love very much. This camera definitely worth the money and you won't regret it!

Reviews.Title: Canon Power Shot SX130IS
Reviews.Author: John D. "John D."
Reviews.Content: This is a great little camera. I own a Canon Rebel, but wanted something a could put in my pocket. It has a very nice zoom lens for a small point and shoot.  The pictures are very good - crisp and clear. The shutter is fast and snaps when you push the button - no waiting which is something important to me. I have not taken any video yet...but look forward to trying it.

Reviews.Title: A little disappointed... expected too much?
Reviews.Author: Hillary Gardner
Reviews.Content: I should start off saying I am a professional and am used to shooting with a 5d and I had the older powershot 600 in my purse forever until my daughter broke the lens. I researched quite a bit as to a new "purse" camera (just shots of my daughter, trips with friends, etc) when I don't want to lug around my pro camera.I was expecting at the least the images to be in focus. It is IS after all. In "auto" mode is the worst... I am used to shooting manual and I had a little bit better luck but not the best. I have found AV to be the best but the stupid flash is driving me crazy. When it is lifted up (the flash) it should go OFF when not on auto.. nope. It decides when it want's to go off. I would say out of 100 pictures, about 40ish are in focus. I really am disappointed since I was hoping for more with a decent camera like this. It is pretty bulky but that's ok...The video capability is great... but it does go in and out of focus and that is annoying.I honestly think that people are so concerned with "high MP" that the camera manufacturers are lacking in so many other things in making these cameras... there needs to be better IS happening along with better quality of these pictures ESP. in AUTO!

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Beneatha Foxx
Reviews.Content: Just got this camera and I am still learning how to use it but so far I have no regrets. The functions are very user friendly where I don't really have to refer to the guide....I will later on but the navigation is super intuitive so I haven't had to yet. I mainly chose this one for the Canon reputation, affordability as a beginning photographer, the 12x wide angle zoom, and 3 inch display screen. The photos so far are great quality. I wanted something a little beyond point and shoot and this camera so far fits the bill.  I did a lot of research online checking out reviews,etc. before I purchased this and it was well worth it. IMPORTANT NOTE: regular AA baterries NOT RECOMMENDED.  I purchased the Sanyo Eneloop 4 Pack AA NiMH Pre-Charged Rechargable Batteries w/ Charger per a happy reviewer (thanks!) and it is perfect.

Reviews.Title: AWESOME camera!
Reviews.Author: Katie M. Padden
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as a late Christmas present yesterday, and opened it right away so that I'd have it for New Year's Eve. WOW - I'm SO glad that *THIS* was the camera that I picked out! (Yes, I had to make sure my fiance got me the right one, LOL)I've used Kodak EasyShares before, and an Olympus, and while they weren't hard to use, I wasn't that impressed. The photos would turn out... okay, but every so often I'd get a blurry pic, or the image stabilization wasn't good, or the software/hardware would stop working, PART of the photo would be blurry...Now granted - I've only had this camera for a DAY. HOWEVER - I'm wicked impressed with it so far. The images come out looking incredible to me (I posted some above with other people's images). I am NOT a professional photographer by any means, but not a beginner, either. This is a good camera for beginners, 'intermediate' users, *OR* professionals. Lots of different settings to use, or an 'Easy' features if you just like to 'point & click', so to speak. Menu's not hard to figure out, and I like how they give you different options & settings to use (nothing too complicated). So easy to use RIGHT out of the box, and the software that comes w/ the camera is good too.I also took a little video clip too, and it came out great. A little blurry at times, but that was MY fault - I moved quickly from one subject to another w/o giving the camera time to adjust for light & distance of objects, but trust me - it would fix itself RIGHT away, and the images in the video were also clean & crisp (the sound was very good too!).So far, no complaints - this camera seems wicked awesome & I'm so happy to have it!

Reviews.Title: Easy to use with great features
Reviews.Author: Biggsmore
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for about a month now and love it. It has a ton of features and is easy to use. It takes great pictures and is fairly easy to figure out. It does gobble up the batteries so rechargeables are a must. Highly reccomend this camera.

Reviews.Title: As good as it gets with a point and shoot!
Reviews.Author: Paul E. Bohannon "phyber.optik"
Reviews.Content: OK, I have purchased my 130is (at Wallyworld for 249 because I couldnt wait) and I have to say that I am impressed, BUT...I have read reviews for over 20 cams in the $150 to $500 range, bought four and returned three to get to this little Canon. For stills there is absolutely no comparison and the reason is color. I took the same shots around my house with this Canon that I previously took with Polaroid (I know), Fuji, Panasonic, Kodak and Sony cams and they all seemed washed out and dull by comparison.Resolution is great. I had no problems with shifty autofocus or camera shake (though I tend to use a tripod when possible). The menu is easy to navigate and the cam is overall very user friendly. So far I haven't even cracked the manual CD - even the custom timers were easy to figure out (an incredibly handy feature that no other cam I read about or used had, but a feature I ). I took a few hundred shots with auto setting and every one was clear, focused, and detailed. And did I mention the color? =WOW!One of the big reasons I was searching for a new cam was to get HD video and this is where the news gets a bit worse, not just for this cam it turns out but for all of them. Somehow I was unaware that there is a file system problem that prevents many cams (INCUDING THIS CANON) from recording HD video clips longer than about 10 minutes (there was also some nonsense about a 5 minute video limit on cams sold in Europe due to import restrictions or some such). I verified this with several SD cards (class 4 and 6) and at 9:59 the cam shuts down (actually powers itself off). Some chat on the net implied that this was as much to prevent overheating as to comply with the FAT32 file structure and I CAN BELIEVE IT, because after 10 minutes of video this cam is REALLY HOT to the touch on the right side!I was able to restart the cam and take additional video clips without incident but after 3 or 4 clips the heat issue concerned me enough to stop recording for a while and let the Canon cool its heels. The quality of these clips was nothing short of A - mazing however. I had almost given up believing that any cam could actually record even decent video for less than $500, but with a tripod and in daytime outside it gives you some absolutely stunning footage (for ten minutes). All the other new cams I bought and tried had video really no better than my 3 year old Fujis 640 x 480 standard def capture, even though they were all supposed to be HD and were set to record in either 720 or 1080. Still, aside from the image being widescreen, actual video on my 42" plasma was disspaointing to say the least. The Canon is a whole other level of video quality than these other brands.After much research it became obvious that optical quality and familiarity with the photographic process was perhaps even more important than techical specs (which increasingly cannot really be trusted) when shopping for cams. For this reason I eventually limited my search to Canon and Nikon products and though I really did like the looks and feel of the Nikon L110 I am convinced that there is no way the Nikon could give any better performance for the money than this Canon. Also the Canon, while not small, still would be far easier to pocket than the larger Nikon and there is something to be said for portability. The Canon IS a battery vampire for sure so I recommend a few sets of AA Enerloops, also at least a class 4 (6 or 10 even better) SD card for HD video without stutter (for 10 minutes).Still, I am happy with the Canon despite its limitations. I guess I will have to save up for a Sanyo FH1a or some such animal to record longer vids. A bummer to be sure, but dont let that stop you from buying this Canon. I really believe it is as good as it gets with point and shoots for 2010!#### UPDATE -- Oct 12, 2010  -- UPDATE #####OK, I have decided that the 10 minute time limit on video is, for me, a dealbreaker. So I have returned the SX130is and am now eagerly eyeing a release date for the Nikon S8100, which I believe CAN record HD video for the limit of the memory card. The Canon still takes great stills, but not as great as I first thought. In fact, the more pics and vids I shot with the Canon the less impressed I became. Really, unless you are in bright sunlight and on a tripod, even the stills just are not as spectacular as they first appeared. I think that first day out with it was just an especially clear and colorful day, because since then subsequent results are not nearly as impressive.

Reviews.Title: Was not happy with this camera
Reviews.Author: Rainey88
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera to use with my 8 month old and the upcoming holidays.  I had read the reviews and everyone seemed to be happy with the camera (with the exception of using AA batteries, which didn't bother me).  I could not be less satisfied.First of all, only about 2 of every 10 pictures came out clear and focused.  This was using auto mode and, yes, holding the button halfway to allow the camera to focus).  Every other shot looked like I wasn't even trying to hold the camera still.Secondly, the lag time between shots was horribly slow.  After a shot, I waited 9 seconds to be able to take the next one (I missed many good shots at a recent wedding because of this).  I'm using the correct speed/type of SD card and I've already tried the low-level format the manual suggests.Last thing: the battery life is quite poor.  I'm using the recommended eneloop batteries and I've already recharged and replaced about 4 times in the last month (maybe 100-150 shots total?)I'm by no means "technologically challenged", and I'm hoping I just got a faulty camera, but I was not happy with this purchase.  I was expected a higher-end P&S; and ended up with something far inferior to my 4-year old Sony Cybershot.

Reviews.Title: Great pictures and video overall, but the flash killed it for me
Reviews.Author: jh
Reviews.Content: Overall, I enjoyed, and really wanted to like this camera, but I was primarily disappointed.The sx130is does a great job compared to its competitors in low light conditions.  It seems like it is programmed to make the pictures too bright though.  More times than not, normal light conditions would be slightly washed out.  It wasn't terrible, but noticeable.I don't care for the menus on newer canon cameras, they seem dumbed down too much to me.The videos do a great job for a camera, I was very pleased with it.I often had issues with this camera using up the batteries quickly, and often without warning.  The indication that the batteries are low come up way too late, often when it can only take a few more pictures.  Then, when testing the batteries after the sx130 will not turn on, they often would have enough juice left for other electronics to use them for many hours more.  If you get this camera, make sure you have spare batteries at all times, it is often a surprise when it needs new ones.I would have given the camera a 4 star rating based on the above, but couldn't primarily because of the flash.  First, I find it amazing that the flash does not raise or come on automatically.  I can't count how many pictures I've missed because I forgot to flip the flash up.  Isn't this 2010 canon?  There is a reminder on the screen, but it is brief, and often you are not reading the screen, but rather looking at the picture instead: especially when trying to take a quick shot of the kids.The other part I couldn't get past is the wait time to take another picture after using the flash.  I have an 8 year old digital canon that charges the flash several times faster than the the sx130is does.  I tried a number of different types and brands of AA batteries, and although some were better than others, none of them were acceptable.  Expect several seconds in between pictures minimum.

Reviews.Title: I Might Buy A Third One
Reviews.Author: C. Dowden
Reviews.Content: Needed a camera in a hurry and bought a SX150 at a mall store.  It was the only camera in their stock that uses AA batteries. Proprietary batteries are a deal breaker for me.A Targus TGC SC610 Case will hold this camera and four more AA batteries easily. Belt loop looks a little iffy, but a toy-quality carabiner as a back-up gives me peace of mind.Liked the 150 so well that I ordered the slightly less featured 130 a couple of days after buying the 150. I'd have gone with the 120, but the price on 130 was better. Any of these cameras should work well.Controls are "intuitive" if you have had a few digital cameras. Pics look great for the documentation and illustration that I do. All the features and gee-wiz may be fantastic for all I know. Do you need a self-timer that starts when you enter the picture and blink your eyes? I don't think I do, but you might.Easy access to manual control is great when images must match in exposure for after-the-fact editing. There's also a variety of white balance possibilities. No raw output tho. Turn off the image review or you spend your time waiting in between pics.Larger size,greater weight, and image stabilization make it easier to hand hold especially in lower light. And image stabilization really works well. This camera could better use strap lugs, rings, and a shoulder strap instead of a wrist strap. Ring type selector around the function set button beats hell out of a slew of tiny buttons and lots of tabbed sub menus. - A little too easy to bump things tho while intending to change one setting and accidentally changing another.Experiments moving from sensitivity of 80 or 100 have been mixed. I'm not impressed. With most digitals and oh so long ago with film I have found that higher sensitivity is a trade-off with noise.This camera uses batteries. Take a bunch of the highest capacity NiMH AA that you can get your hands on. Make sure they are in good shape and fully charged! I'm getting 100 to 150 shots out of each pair of new 2300s before getting a low battery warning. Or about two thirds the number of shots from what I got out of my previous camera. - Have to figure that features like image stabilization are not a loss-free operation.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: French Fry
Reviews.Content: The Canon Powershot SX130Is 12.1 MP digital camera has totally met my expectations.  Here's the story of how I chose this camera: My daughter is a real camera buff and a sort of amatuer photographer.  She had purchased this camera so she could pack it in her purse at times when she didn't want to haul her big one around.  She knows a lot more about cameras than I do.  She was pleased with it so I thought that it would be a good purchase for me as well.  My previous camera did not take good pics when stabilization was important.  For example, pics of my granddaughter's high school band performing on the field always came out fuzzy. So I really needed something that would meet my needs and dependable.I had read reviews about the batteries not lasting very long but I have found that is not the case.  I wanted a camera with AA batteries and that was another good feature of this camera.  AA batteries are reasonable in price and can be found in a variety of stores so it's not a problem to carry extras.  I have taken a lot of pics and I still have the original AA batteries in my camera.A nice feature that was not in the description is the flash.  It is located on top of the camera and pops up easily with a flick of the finger.I am extremely pleased with the purchase of this camera.  Additionally, I saved a good bit of money by ordering it from Amazon compared to the prices in the stores.

Reviews.Title: True PowerShot!
Reviews.Author: ConstantMotion
Reviews.Content: I am very happy with this camera.  Spent a day out in misty weather taking macro shots and I couldn't be happier with the quality and images that I got!!!  Still learning about all the different features... I'll figure them out as I play with it more.  A VERY big plus for me is that it takes AA batteries.  As a hiker it is important for me to know that I'll be able to have the battery power throughout my hike.  This camera also provides great opportunity on the trail of being able to get the quality shot I want without the weight of a larger camera.

Reviews.Title: A little bulky but convenient
Reviews.Author: Puffin
Reviews.Content: This camera uses 2 AA batteries that are widely available. It's convenient when the electrical outlet is not available for recharging. It's a little bulky but if it fits in the shirt pocket. Outdoor pictures are sharp and clear but indoor pictures without adequate light are kind of blurry.

Reviews.Title: Sweet Camera
Reviews.Author: TLTN
Reviews.Content: We used this on several vacations now and really liked it. Makes beautiful photos. This is the second one we owned, the first one was stolen. So we truly like this camera a lot to replace it with another of the same brand. Good camera!

Reviews.Title: Good color and quality, but a little slow
Reviews.Author: Rob W. "Professional amateur"
Reviews.Content: If you're looking for a camera to take nice pictures with, then you probably wouldn't go too far wrong with this one.  It's fast to learn, it has easy to understand pre-sets, a friendly menu and a very clear display.  In low light, the pictures are slightly grainy without the flash, but it takes them quickly enough on auto-mode to avoid the motion-blur that always plagued low-light pictures with our old camera, which is good enough at least for candid snap-shots so long as you aren't looking to sell them.The color seems pretty accurate, too.  Our older camera struggled particularly with shades of purple for some reason, while this one seems to have no such problems.  Every picture seems to come out well colored, and if it's in good light or with the flash, it's crisp and clear too.Its Achilles heels (one per foot for twice the legend) are its erratic shot-to-shot time, and its enthusiastic devouring of batteries.Sometimes, you'll take a shot, and the next shot will be available quickly.  But other times, you'll snap a picture and then find yourself waiting, the camera's screen black and empty while it prepares to let you take another.  The time between shots can be frustrating on occasion, especially if you're using the flash, and if you're looking to be able to take a lot of shots quickly then this definitely isn't the camera for you.  Our oldest digicam, a Nikon Coolpix 3100, was noticeably faster shot-to-shot than any camera we've owned since even when using flash, and that probably spoiled us.  But even so, this one seems particularly slow.Its other issue is batteries.  If you use regular alkalines, this camera will quickly eat them, and you'll find yourself queueing up to buy more.  The up side is that it uses regular batteries, so you can simply use chargeable NiMH or Eneloops, and carry extras with you; and it chews its way through those batteries much more slowly.  It'll still eat them, though, as it only uses two -- a trade-off that gives you slightly reduced battery life in exchange for a lighter, less unwieldy body than a camera that uses four.  Personally I'd happily take the reduced battery life and carry a few spares in my pocket to deal with it.Overall, though, I like this camera.  It's not everything I'd want in a camera, but in the price range I could afford, I was never going to get that.  And for under $200, its flaws are easily outweighed by its qualities.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera for the money
Reviews.Author: reviewer155
Reviews.Content: Pros:An excellent performer for the home user.Takes amazing photos. Powerful zoom lens 12xClose ups are also awesome.Takes good High Def video. (video is full screen when playing back on computer)Can zoom in and out slowly while recording video.Good enough to substitute for video camera for basic video tasks.Image stabilizer during video works well. Dramatically reduces "shaky" video.Uses ordinary AA batteriesVery pleasedCons:A bit too bulky for the shirt pocket.Eats batteries rapidly. You need to use Lithium or rechargables.Lag time between photos.

Reviews.Title: Another great little Canon
Reviews.Author: Marilyn Armstrong
Reviews.Content: I got this to replace my Powershot A650 which after long and heavy use, up and died. I was almost as upset as i would be at the passing of a dear friend. I loved that camera.The results from this camera are as good as from the 650, at least so far. I grant you I haven't had it very long, but I've run all the tests and it has passed with flying colors. I have heard that it's a real pig with batteries, so I've invested in top quality eneloops and will be sure to carry extras with me whenever I am going to be shooting. I've always carried lots of spare batteries anyhow as a matter of principle.Some people hate the fact that the camera uses AAs. Personally, I love knowing I can get batteries anywhere and am not tethered to being somewhere where I can recharge a proprietary battery. It's a personal matter.I do not do much video shooting, so I was really unable to rate the video quality. Every once in a blue moon a shoot a little video, but so rarely that it's not a matter of concern for me. You'll have to read other reviewers for that information. I really don't know. As a still camera, the pictures are sharp, it focuses quickly and accurately and the flash shots are surprisingly good. I don't like flash, so I am predisposed to not like the results ... I was surprised at the high quality from this little camera. I much prefer the pop up flash to a built in one ... if you don't want flash, you don't have to mess with settings. Just don't pop it up and it won't fire.It isn't a DSLR. I wish I could afford one, but right now, I can't. When I finally get the money together, I will happily move on, but a camera like this is always a useful sidekick, even when you have a full DSLR rig. There are plenty of times when you don't want to haul the big gun.I have read complaints that the viewfinder is fuzzy. I do not find it so. Do I miss having one that flips out? No, actually, I don't. I know it's supposed to be better, but I like this better and always found having to look to the side to see the picture awkward. Do I wish it had a viewfinder? Honestly? Not really. As an eyeglass wearer, I've always found it hard to really see well through a viewfinder. If I had it, I would probably use it occasionally, but I don't miss it. If it's a big deal for you, well, this camera doesn't have one. Other Canon models do.This is my third Canon during that last decade. I have loved them all. The first one is still alive and well and my son loves it. Before that, I was using an SLR and actual film and working professionally. Considering that I used to be a pro back in the day, I am remarkably satisfied with this camera, as I was by its predecessors. Canon makes a fine product.A Note: 6 months later:It's STILL  great little camera. Using the high end rechargeable AAs (Sanyo Enyloops), I get a very good battery life. Of course I carry spares too. I love knowing I can get extra batteries anywhere pretty much.It dependably and without compaint takes excellent pictures. It isn't the fastest P&S.; It doesn't have the longest lens. It isn't the most compact nor does it have the most bells and whistles. However: it has everything I really need in a point & shoot camera. If I want more, I'll use one of my interchangeable lens cameras ... one of the 4/3 Olympus most likely. I don't do much video so it remains a non-issue for me. I also don't shoot much using flash, although when I have, this camera works just fine.For the price, it has an excellent feature set. The full override was critical to me: everything else was optional. It's big enough so I can see the screen without squinting, small enough to drop into my purse and go, no special bag needed. It isn't my primary camera and wasn't intended to be, but it is a fantastic back-up camera and I love knowing that if I'm not in a position to recharge a proprietary battery, I can pick up replacement batteries anywhere. In my opinion, everyone who shoots a lot should have ONE camera that works on AAs ... just in case.You can spend more and if it is going to be your primary camera, you may want some features it doesn't have. But for most purposes, this is just fine. A fine general purpose shooter and a great "extra" camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera if you know how to use it...
Reviews.Author: Sim_Perf "Wise Engineer"
Reviews.Content: Pros:- This is a great camera; I love the picture qualities and sharpness.- I would recommend buying this for sure.- 12x optical zoom is very useful especially capturing pictures of sports event or nature.- Low light picture with Av and fast moving picture with Tv mode works great.Cons:- Very powerful camera with lots of options, one has to get familiar with all different option to utilize it better.- When the flash is ON, write speed is impacted drastically. But with Av option (not moving), pictures without flash captured perfectly in low light.- Switching between options is time consuming and you may lose the moment.- Auto mode is useless for me as most of the pictures are shaky. My normal operating mode is Tv or Av based on the situation.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera for what you pay for
Reviews.Author: Arthas "arthurqx641"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the SX130 as a replacement for my 6 year old Kodak Easyshare. The Kodak was a great workhorse, but it was time for her to retire. I am VERY satisfied to have this Canon as the replacement!This is not a full review; rather it's a set of observations I got from using the camera.-The camera is perfect for casual & amateur photography! I use it to take pictures of friends/family, as well as pretty sunsets, beautiful seafronts, and macro shots of circuit boards :)-Invest in quality AA rechargeable batteries & charger! Otherwise you will find yourself hurting and frustrated with this camera. It has a 3V DC-in port that allows you to power the camera for extended periods with AC or an external battery pack. Great for time lapse setups.-The SX130 is considerably hefty for a point & shoot style camera- around the weight of a can of soda.-Settings are decently accessible in full manual mode, including manual focus. On the other hand, there's a [DUMMY MODE] that locks out all buttons except shutter and zoom. PERFECT for particular people :)-When filming it is possible to zoom (slowest speed). The recorded servo motor noise is noticeably audible in quiet conditions.-It takes a LONG time for flash to recharge. Shot-to-shot time crawls in at ~1shot/sec. Not the ideal camera if you take many burst shots.-The lens have no threads to screw a barrel on. There is a lens adapter for the SX120 that may work for this camera too.-The scene settings are fun to play around with. Fisheye and selective color accent are fun to play around, though most effects can be replicated in post processing. It also has smile & wink detection which takes a picture whenever it detects a smile or wink. It's pretty accurate ;)-There IS a working version of CHDK out for this camera! The firmware addition gives the camera much more utility (RAW files, live histogram, zebra exposure warning, 30min long shutter shots, auto bracketing setups, time lapse photography capabilities, remote sync, etc. etc.) Things you do not expect to accomplish with a compact becomes available with CHDK.

Reviews.Title: A great camera
Reviews.Author: S. Harris
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera right after thanksgiving.  I have really enjoy trying out it's many features.  Did some night shots with a variety of settings.  Low light, auto, flash & no flash, snow.  They came out best with low light, no flash.  Took very good quality pictures of our kids outside in snow and against green bushes.  Did great video's  Did not care for the Canon sx210 as they put the flash in a poor location.  Have not felt the speed is too slow....I really wanted quality over speed if I had to choose...and this is quality pictures.  I did order from Amazon the eneloop sanyo four pack batteries and charger....it was $16.50 and was rated good by many people.  Well worth the extra cost as going through AA batteries is not great.  That seemed to be the only person really unhappy and returning the camera.  This is a great camera...have fun and try different shots in different setting and times of day.

Reviews.Title: A step backwards
Reviews.Author: GeValero
Reviews.Content: After 5 years of owning the Power Shot A620 I thought it was time for an upgrade (I know, why fix something that's not broken?). I had taken thousands of pictures with this old model and I thought the colors were infinitely better than with any other brand but I liked the idea that these new camera had a really good zoom and bigger viewing screen so I tried to avoid giving importance to the many warning reviews about its low battery life (which are accurate by the way). I realize this model only carries 2 batteries but overall I would say you'll spend about twice as much  than with older ones, for example, just try zooming while shooting video and no matter how new the batteries are, you'll likely get a "low battery" warning (I'm not kidding).But what really has me down about this new camera are the colors which are mediocre at best. There is very little contrast  and faces turn out rather yellowish. With my old A620 you could choose modes such as INDOOR and NIGHT SCENE which would greatly improve results and this new model is suppossed to do automatically with "suppossed" being the key word here.Now I'm stuck with these new camera which I have no idea what to do with. Until recently I thought I would never buy anything but Cannon but this idea is history. For now I'm going back to my old A620 and will someday look into buying a newer model but the only thing about such I can say for sure is that Cannon has lost a customer for good.

Reviews.Title: Canon, the competition is getting better ! !
Reviews.Author: Bears Fan Jim "qm2-703"
Reviews.Content: At first, liked this camera a lot.  Has good heft, but not heavy. Love the buttons.  Liked the color of pics at first, but began to get slightly annoyed by the continuously saturated results....pretty, but not reality.PROS:  Good feel and not too heavy or light.  Good included software.  Good but not great low-light no-flash performance.  Good flash reach for most shots.  Nice stabilization, in that I never really noticed it.CONS:  Soft focus in the zoom the farther you go out.  Panning during indoor videos too often produces a wave/ripple effect.  Cannot open batt door w/o losing power (no hot-swapping SDHC cards...)  Eats alkalines like candy (but Sanyo Eneloops solve that)I wound up preferring the Lumix ZS5 for if looking for a compact, and Lumix FZ35 if looking for more features and more zoom.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the price
Reviews.Author: CSS
Reviews.Content: Price I got it $179.99 with 4GB Flash drive with Amazon Prime i.e. no shipping (also no tax) on Black Friday 2010.Giving u the price details and date as I am comparing with other cameras in this range.I read many reviews about the flash, batteries, image quality, various options/modes, manual settings, etc.Some said that it doesn't fit in the pocket. So went to a shop before I purchased to know its size. It holds in a pocket if ur pocket is big enough (most of the men's casual trousers). Not small nor big, it is of medium size. So to me it didn't matter much with the size. Pretty good on size for me. And batteries I got Sanyo eneloop, so it does good with these batteries as they don't die out soon. Also the discharge rate is too slow. So I don't have to bother about recharging them after many days. If ur camera is out of batteries u can get AA batteries from most of the stores near by. So not in danger of running out of batteries. But it is the biggest negative for this camera as usual batteries die out fast. Regarding flash, after I read out the reviews that I need to pop up the flash when I take the photos, when I took the first few shots I missed it. All the photos would have been great if I had popped up the flash. But over time I will definitely pop up the flash when needed. But the image quality is good when u use flash. Next time if I forget I can check from the preview that it is not the best shot, then "POP up the FLASH" should come out of my brain. So let's see how it works. There are some nice features like manual focus, accent mode, fish eye, miniature effect, vivid colors, etc. Also u can increase the power of flash if u r not satisfied. Video is too good, but the file size of the video is huge. You can zoom in the video mode and the quality is still as good as it is without zoom.For me it is one of the best cameras in its range. Also if you use all the features and the manual controls then this one is good. If you want to use it in auto mode or for sports action or u want a quick snap then this is not good for you. Still this camera lacks powerful image stabilization. My old old Olympus did too good on Image stabilization. It freezes the motion and never got a blurred shot with it. But this one if you shake u can see the blurred objects in the photo.Will add my experience and photos as I use it and update this review.

Reviews.Title: A step up from my pocket point and shoot but no DSLR
Reviews.Author: E. E. Blabac
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I was looking for a camera that took better pictures than my pocket, freeze/shock/waterproof Olympus.  I read several reviews of this camera and at around $250, decided it was the one I wanted for the price.  I went to my local Fry's Electronics and bought it and brought it home to play with it.  Right out of the box, it took much better pictures than my Olympus.I was looking to learn how to take better pictures, so I signed up for a digital camera class at my local Ritz Camera Store.  I learned a lot, but what I learned is that this camera couldn't take quite the pics I was hoping to take.  For instance, I was really hoping to take portraits with blurry backgrounds.  Well, I can get that to some extent, but not in the extreme.  I also learned how to set some of the manual controls, but really, I can't tell the pictures (except in the instances of the really bad pics) between those I set manually and the ones that were set on an auto program.I've uploaded some photos I've taken with their photo info so you can see for yourself.Also, as others have mentioned, this camera eats batteries.  I went through a set taking test photos yesterday. I've been using disposable alkaline batteries.  I'm hoping to fix this by getting some Eneloop batteries.Overall, if you are looking to take great pics of your friends, family, kids, pets, vacations, this is great.  If you are looking to take artistic photos save your money and go with an SLR.UPDATE - Eneloop batteries work great! I went on a trip and was able to go 2 days between battery changes (during a sightseeing tour).  I'm not sure if its eneloop batteries specifically or just the more expensive batteries, but its fantastic.Also, I LOVE this camera. Its my favorite. I've taken some amazing pics.  Its truly great.UPDATE - May 2013 - 3 years later and the camera is still going strong!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Canon Lover
Reviews.Content: Yes I am disappointed in this camera. No, I don't hate Canon. All of my cameras have been Canons. The main reason I bought this camera is because of the it's video capability. A camera under $200 that shoots 720 video? Awesome. The first red flag is when I placed the alkaline batteries that came with the camera in it to play around. The "low battery" indicator came on within minutes. I know a digital camera can be a drain on alkalines so I thought nothing of it. I took it to my father's house for Christmas eve planning to shoot plenty of video of my niece and nephew. I was using NiMH rechargeables that last for days in my SX10 IS. The SX130 died after less than 10 minutes of shooting video. Yes, the low battery indicator came on almost immediately. The second red flag is a problem I encountered shooting video. The focus was constantly "hunting" and causing blurry scenes. Sometimes it would blur for one a second or two and sometimes it would blur for 10-15 seconds. It was extremely frustrating. There was plenty of light on in the room. On the plus side, pic and video quality are excellent (as one would expect from Canon).

Reviews.Title: Wonderful camera
Reviews.Author: Mel Rose
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera a little over a year ago for specific reasons. I wanted a decent quality camera, but a cheaper price. This camera was one of the ones I was looking at and finally decided to get. It's like getting a professional camera at a fraction of the cost and in a compact size.The reason I purchased this camera was because I needed a decent camera that would do everything I wanted to. Also I was planning a trip to Puerto Rico and I wanted to make sure I had a nice camera to take pictures. I've taken pictures of places down there, of flowers, of people, of nature, sunsets, etc. My favorite setting, besides auto, is black and white and any vivid settings as well.-This camera has amazing zoom. I was able to zoom in to someone all the way across a coliseum and it came out perfect.-Runs on AA batteries. While I'd prefer to not have to deal with batteries at all, it's nice that it's just AA batteries that you can get anywhere. You can get rechargeable ones if you like.-Small enough to fit into a pocket. Though, I'd still recommend getting a cover to protect it.-Different settings to play around with. You can take pictures on the plain auto setting, or you can play around with different settings. There's black/white, sepia, vivid, and so much more. You can choose inside, outside, nighttime, more of a certain color such as blues or reds coming out. I haven't been able to play with each and every setting, but there is a good amount there that you can choose from and find one that works for you and the location you're working with.-You can edit pictures or crop them right there, right away. There's a couple of pictures I took that I need to crop and I hoped I didn't have to wait till I got home to do that. Luckily, I was able to take care of that right from the camera.-Not spill proof, but pretty close to it. Recently, I accidentally spilt orange juice in my purse, soaking everything, including my camera. I thought it was ruined. But, I took everything out, dried it out as best I could and let it sit for a while. It still works after all of that. Of course, it is a smidge slower, but overall, it works the same as it did before. Gotta say I'm impressed and surprised about that.There is also a video section as well, but I wasn't all that impressed with it. It does do pretty good with video, just like the pictures, but the sound is horrible. I tried to record something at Luray Caverns, but I couldn't hear a thing from it later on. Also, there's a ten minute limit as well. I didn't know that but would have liked to know as I did try to record things that were longer than 10 minutes. Overall, though, it's not bad. I don't use video too much anyways.I've seen some reviews mentioning dust and dirt, but I haven't had that problem as of yet. I clean the screen as best I can and keep it in a case when I'm not using it.I've also seen some reviews mentioning that it takes horrible pictures, but that's not the case. It does take amazing pictures. But the thing is, it's also depends on the person using it. My sister can't take as good of pictures as I can, so all of hers don't turn out as well. If someone can't take pictures, it doesn't matter if you spend $5 or $5000 on a camera, you're not going to be able to take good pictures. Having a good camera helps, but it's also the person taking the pictures. My uncle, who has been a  professional photographer for over 30 years, agrees that this camera is a good camera.I've taken tons of pictures with this camera. Some even while moving in cars and planes - some of them didn't turn out as well as hoped for. I've taken pictures of weather, clouds, flowers, people and so on. I've taken pictures in different types of weather as well - from sunny warm weather, to rainy weather, to snowy weather, even in the middle of a hurricane. There camera hasn't had a problem in any temperature. Though, it did get a bit steamy during the hurricane and covered with too much rain, but that's to be expected.Overall, I love this camera and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a decent camera with a lower price tag. Or just a decent camera period.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera
Reviews.Author: Edith Brown
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent camera and easy to use.  I expecially like the flash feature.  The flash won't fire unless you raise it.  I like the big LCD screen to review pictures.  I would like to advise everyone to use the wrist strap.  I didn't with the first one and dropped it on a hard floor and ruined the lens.  This time I purchased a camera warranty which will replace the camera or pay for repairs.  I liked the first Canon enough to buy another one almost like the first.  I really like the 12X zoom lens.  I haven't found anything about this camera I don't like.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: John T. Mclaughlin
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. The settings available couldn't be better. But, the previous reviews about the batteries are correct. You must use rechargeable which last as long on one charge as do conventional batteries on my Pentax DSLR. The size of this camera is also good. Too many of the point and shoot models are too small to handle and those I have tried are virtually useless in available light indoors. This camera, set correctly is great in indoor available light. The only real complaint I have is the lack of a viewfinder. I find it very difficult, sometimes impossible, to compose a shot using the back screen outdoors on a bright day.After much frustration outdoors I bought a Hoodman Hood Loupe which solves the problem of outdoor composing, but it's awkward to use and very overpriced at $77.Shortly after writing this review I dropped this camera on a concrete walk and that was the end of it. Strongly suggest using a wrist or neck strap with it.

Reviews.Title: Grainy in low light, AUTO tends to use high ISO AND low sutter speed?!?
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: SUMMARY - After all this rant (typoes included, my apologies) it is still a good camera. If I use flash, which I don't like to, I know it would be better. daytime shooting, this thing performs perfectly. Macro is amazing, the lens almost touches the subject and can still focus! For the cost this can't be beat. if you are saying this camera is too big, this was not a camera for your demographic to begin with so look elsewhere. If you are a dSLR shooter looking for control over your exposure, seriosuly consider trying this or their SX150IS out!I saw this on sale at Target for $99 since they were trying to push the SX150IS and phase out the SX130IS. A few years ago I had the SX110IS which I absolutely loved but sold it because of how quick it drains the AA batteries, since then Sanyo has released their Eneloop Lithium batteries and I have a bunch of them for my gadgets so battery was no longer an issues. REMEMBER if you want to be happy with this camera get ENELOOPS!I'm a dSLR shooter but wanted a P&S; with a longer lens reach than your usual small camera. I have an iPhone 4S and that camera is already pretty amazing, but the lack of optical zoom makes it useless at times. Also because I like to have the OPTION of manual control this camera was perfect...so I thought.Originally I had gotten the Nikon S9100 at Target, they had it for sale for $199. I LOVED this camera except there were two issues I was unable to live with, 1- I think there was an issue with the dial, a few time I turned it to auto mode, but the camera would be in scene mode, it would take a few more back and forth rotation before it actually would get to the auto mode. 2- there may have been a speck of dust on the sensor because when I zoom in, you would see a blurred area that would not move when you move the camera. the s9100 has a backside illuminated CMOS sensor which was AWESOME in low light, there was never shutter lag, not even in a dim room, you press the shutter and it takes a picture right away. Sadly reading the reviews showed that it had many issues.Seeing that I had great experience with the old SX110IS I thought this camera would also rock now that it's three years later. the SX130IS performed horribly in dim light, most of my pictures were blurred when I used AUTO. The AUTO mode doesn't seem to be very smart, because it would use a higher ISO...which would be fine, but this sensor produces way too much noise even at ISO400. The smart thing would be to use a lower ISO, larger aperture and slow the shutter speed. if I take a picture in AUTO and then take a picture with manual, manual will take a better picture. I would like Canon to make the AUTO mode calculate better. but THIS is why I got this camera, I have 100% control of the picture since I understand photography, but I shouldn't have to, it should be capable to doing just fine in AUTO.I am going to attach TWO pictures I took with the camer in a very dark setting, the better one would be using MANUAL ,no flash, I set up (10 seconds shutter, f/3.4, ISO 200), the dark one will be AUTO with no flash (shutter was 1/8, f/3.4, ISO800) I have no idea why the Auto setting would want to to do this since the picture would be useless! If you get this camera, you have to realize that you can make better judgement on the exposure!HERE ARE A FEW MORE SHORT ISSUE I HAVE:Video Mode - it caps out at 10 minutes. WTH?!?!Selector Wheel -  too stiff (unlike the old SX110IS which was perfect) I find myself pushing down instead of rotating itUSB/AV port door - STOP making these things so hard to pull open. I'm a clean neat person, I don't usually have nails that long. this is not a weather proof camera stop making me look for tools to open this!Zoom - thanks for letting us zoom while in movie mode. I understand you want the mic to not pick up the zoom noise when recording video, but you need to have a option of letting it zoom faster. you've slowed it down way too much when recording videoVideo - I don't like the fact that there's no dedicated record video button on this version, it's on the dial...this was changed in the SX150ISLCD - way too low res for this day and ago. the pictures don't look that good on this LCD, the Nikon S9100 is BEAUTIFUL.

Reviews.Title: 100% Happy
Reviews.Author: Travis D
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for $90 on sale. I am a novice when it comes to all things camera but fairly techie otherwise. I was at first thrown off by the megapixel number of just 12.1 and didn't realize how important the 12x zoom was but I have used this all day outdoors and it took great photos. I don't have steady hands at all and my wrist is not strong due to a biking accident. Either way no blurry photos and it was great.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera, especially for the price!
Reviews.Author: emilyelizabeth669
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera before I went on a trip to Africa.  I was personally looking for something in between a DSLR and a a point-and-shoot.  This camera was absolutely perfect! While it isn't as compact as a point-and-shoot, the quality of the images more than compensates for that.  The zoom is incredible, and I found that the images I had taken were on par with , and in certain situations better than,those on my trip who had brought DSLRs. I used it mainly on automatic mode, only switching to manual in certain low-light situations.  I was completely impressed with its performance.  I used non-rechargable batteries for my trip and took thousands of pictures while only changing them once (I believe they were some fancy kind of Energizer ones).  I purchased rechargable batteries and have yet to use them.  To me, having the option to use your rechargable batteries while also having regular backups is important in a place where electricity may not always be stable.  I highly recommend this camera!

Reviews.Title: GREAT little camera
Reviews.Author: I am new to Canon
Reviews.Content: I am so impressed with my purchase.  It is far better than I expected.I wanted a camera which uses AA batteries & in my opinion, I could not have chosen a better one than this Canon.I have always used HP's in the past (about 4 of them).  I am hard on a camera because I am a photo fanatic.  My camera goes where I go & is always in my purse.I cannot rate the video since I have not used it yet.I did research after research on this particular camera & I have found where they mentioned different things they did not like, I have no problems.  They did say it was a heavier camera because of the batteries.  It is heavier, even compared to my other cameras which also had 2 AA batteries.  To me, it actually makes it easier to stabilize the camera.You can use it for a point & shoot, or if you want to get more technical, you can do that too.I would highly recommend this camera for anyone.

Reviews.Title: A Good Bargain
Reviews.Author: Truckpipe
Reviews.Content: I purchased this for my wife as a birthday present. Neither she nor I are expert photographers.  With the include instructions and the Auto setting we have been able to get some great shots and are hoping to get better.  Easy to use, good zoom and fine pixel quality.  Like most digital cameras it's a little hard on batteries, so we carry 4 rechargeables if we leave the house.  No complaints!  Would recommend this to anyone who is not in the market for a professional rig but wants quality candid/family photos.

Reviews.Title: Overall excellent, a few tips
Reviews.Author: Taffyrn "taffyrn"
Reviews.Content: 1. Get the Sanyo Eneloop rechargeable batteries... they last the longest and charge really fast....2. Get to know how to use it.... I shoot with a DSLR professionally, but love my SX 130 IS for everyday! good videos and pictures from this.3. My only real gripe is when you use flash it takes a while to right to disc, which means I am waiting a good 10-20 seconds to take the next shot, which can be a problem.... but that is really the only problem I have found with this camera.... overall it shoots great pics in a variety of situations and the thats whether my 2.5 year old takes the pic or myself:0Overall highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful Camera
Reviews.Author: T. E.
Reviews.Content: I spent weeks studying digital cameras of various specs and price ranges and decided on this camera based on the combination of the good price and 12x optical zoom. Retail it sells for $229 plus sales tax so any price you get on Amazon will beat what you'd pay at the store.  I absolutely love my camera. The vast majority of photos have come out vivid and beautiful, and the Zoom is amazing!  When you combine the optical and digital zoom, you get 48x which admittedly isn't as clear as staying with a 12x optical only, but it allows you the ability to capture some pretty amazing shots at a distance.One feature some may not like, but I love is that it takes AA batteries.  I simply use rechargables or lithium and they last a Very long time.  The batteries it comes with are weak and are best used for a remote control.Overall, I Love this camera so much, I purchased a 2nd one as a Father's Day gift & I know he'll enjoy using it as much as I am.

Reviews.Title: ALL this for around 200 bucks!!!
Reviews.Author: porkchop
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera that had very little noise in the pictures! My last camera took pictures that had too much of this in almost all the shots. I am pleased to say this camera does well with noise. I see very little and really have to look for it. Some other things I LIKE about this camera are it's great optical Image Stabilization, Low noise in pictures, color accuracy, Size that feels just right in my hands,Large view screen,Easy to navigate menu,Great flash,wonderful low light pictures, also it uses double a batteries. Things I DON'T LIKE are no view finder,short battery life however after the alkaline batteries were dead I replaced them with rechargeable batteries and i get more shots from them than i did the alkaline type. I am very pleased with this camera. The fact that you can also go to a great manual mode is nice as well for those who like more control. I will say for those who like a simple mode the auto mode works fantastic too. I just got back from a trip near the blue ridge parkway and must say almost all the shots i took came out great and the few that didnt were my fault not the cameras. I wanted a camera that takes the best pictures in my price range and I feel even after owning this camera for a while I made the right choice. Picture quality is what you want at the end of the day and I have to agree with others that you won't find a better camera than this for around 200 bucks. No camera is perfect but this one is close. The only thing i do is make sure i carry an extra pair of fully charged batteries with me in case i take more shots than i usually do. That is easy to do and well worth it for a camera that takes this good of pictures.

Reviews.Title: Worth every penny!
Reviews.Author: MamaMia
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for such a good price on black friday 2010 but didn't know much about it before I snatched it up. Turns out it is exactly the camera I was looking for. If you are looking for a crystal clear picture, super fast shutter speed (lesser cameras were too slow for my 1 year old to keep his eyes open for the flash), 10x plus zoom, camera/video capable, super easy to use, and not a big complicated digital SLR then this is it. You will probably as an average consumer and photographer just keep it in "auto" mode most of the time. Unless you are really into playing with your camera then you will probably use all the settings at one time or another. There are not so many that it's confusing. This camera packs a big punch with great zoom ans so simple to use. I LOVE this camera and will not buy a different brand in the future.

Reviews.Title: Another Easy to use Canon Camera
Reviews.Author: Larry  L. "Larry"
Reviews.Content: I've owned a Canon PowerShot A590 for years now and abused the heck out of it. I considered other brands for my next camera before settling on this one because once again Canon offered everything I want. I'm not anywhere near a professional photographer, but I want something more than just point and shoot and this is a good hybrid. It has Easy and Automatic modes but also lets you make some adjustments if you're gutsy enough (which I'm usually not).I like this model because it has 12x zoom, and I also love the video capabilities. I bought it because I needed it to shoot a video the very next day, and I was up and running with no learning curve even though it differs from my old model. I was extremely pleased with the quality of the video too. I haven't tried it in low light yet; that was a weakness of my old Canon so I'm expecting some improvements there. But I mainly shoot during the day or inside with lights on so that wasn't enough of a detriment to push me to a different model.This camera does have its drawbacks, but they're about the same as my old Canon. Chief among them is that it's a terrible battery eater, so I always bring many, many spares. It also has a somewhat slow reset speed, but part of that is due to a setting that can be changed, as well as the type of SD card you use. None of those things are show stoppers for me, given this camera's other advantages. I don't mind the pop-up flash (which my old Canon did not have) because it ensures I won't get flash if I don't want it.I recommend this model for people who want something more than a basic model, but still want a camera that can totally take over for them if needed. It's the perfect middle of the road between "I don't know what I'm doing" and "I want to make some adjustments, but need some help too."

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot SX130IS Digital Camera
Reviews.Author: Randy May
Reviews.Content: My wife and I wanted a simple digital camera that would take good clear pictures day or night without making a lot of changes to the camera settings. Just point the camera, focus it and shoot. This doesn't seem like a lot to ask but evidently it is because  we went through a total of six different cameras before trying this one. Some of those six  were much more expensive than this Canon PowerShot SX130IS but none of them would take clear pictures if the light wasn't just right. We ordered this one from Amazon because we knew we could return it if we didn't like it. We didn't have to worry about that because we have been pleased with it right out of the box. For people who don't pretend to be a pro with a camera, for people who just want to take great clear pictures almost everytime, this camera is the one.

Reviews.Title: Great camera at a lovely price
Reviews.Author: Wawa
Reviews.Content: This camera is excelent, specially if you consider that you can have at under $ 200.Whereas other reviews complain about poor battery life, I've been using it with rechargeable Sanyo Eneloop batteries with no problems, shooting around 400 pictures and some videos with just having to change de batteries once.Image quality is excelent, and manual setups (if knowing how to use them) can enhance it notably.With its 12x zoom, you can take pictures at people without them noticing (like in a party), making them look more natural than with regular digital camera (although zooming too much will requiere a steady holding).The only drawback is that it is a little bulky to carry around (it is not a pocket camera). But considering the quality, versatility and price, it is a great buy.

Reviews.Title: Great second camera
Reviews.Author: Alfa
Reviews.Content: I have a Cannon SLR and needed a small camera to carry around for occasional snaps.  I initially looked at this camera, but thought it was too fragile for my purposes.  After reading a few reviews, I changed my mind and bought one.  I've had it for a few weeks now and I think it is a great camera for my purposes.  It is very easy to use and takes great pictures outdoors.  I carry it around everywhere I go and experiment quite a lot with pictures.  I still take out the SLR for special events, but I am very happy with the results.The only issue I have is with the flash and low light situations.  The flash is not very strong and low light shots are challenging.  But this is not a major issue for me since I do not take a lot of low light pictures.Great value for money.

Reviews.Title: Love the zoom!
Reviews.Author: LG22
Reviews.Content: Love the 12x zoom on this point & shoot camera. Excellent quality for outside pix. Good solid size, yet still manageable to use for hiking. My only frustration is the shutter lag indoors. Still experience missed opportunities of that special photo moment because the camera is still thinking. No matter how hard I press the shutter, there's a delay before the camera takes the picture and the moment is lost of facial expressions, pet antics, etc. Otherwise, I'm extremely satisfied with the mega zoom and the quality of the photos. Plus being able to use AA batteries. I use rechargables, but it's comforting to know that in a pinch I could run to the store and plop in regular AA to get through an event until I could recharge.

Reviews.Title: A Neat Little Camera- Not Perfect but Overall a Very Good Choice
Reviews.Author: frednmoe@fairhope.com
Reviews.Content: Pros:-The camera feels heavy for its size. I like the heft in my hands when taking pictures.-Fit and finish are good, with one minor caveat for the battery compartment. (See Cons, below.)-The LCD (viewing screen) is large, and very bright. You can actually see the image out-of-doors, in the shade. Brightness is adjustable- I have it racked-up all the way.-Focusing range is remarkable, from about ½ inch to infinity.-Crucially, normal indoor & outdoor photos are quite good- contrast and saturation are adjustable, and sharpness is very good for a point-and-shoot camera.-12.1 megapixels is a big image, which permits cropping and selecting areas of photos, without ending up with a small "thumbnail" snapshot.-The price for all of these features and capabilities is great- I paid $198 from Amazon; reduced by $20 a few days later!Cons-A printed owner's manual does not come with the camera. If you want one to carry out with your new camera, print it yourself, 180 pages, from the PDF file on the CD that comes in the box, or download it from the internet. This irks me.-The many reviewer complaints about battery life are justified, though it should be clear that a camera with all these bells and whistles, that uses off-the-shelf AA batteries is just going to be hard on batteries.  Don't even think about using alkaline batteries in this camera, unless you plan to carry a pocketful when you go out. Though not specifically recommended in the owner's manual, I use lithium batteries. Pricey, but I get 200 - 300 photos from a pair. Battery life depends on how often the camera is powered up and down, and mainly, on how often the flash is fired.-One thing that bothers me a little is the battery and SD card compartment. It's under a lot of spring tension, does not move real smoothly; makes me a little nervous- I'd hate to break it.-The flash has to be manually popped-up for use. Like me, you will forget, miss the on-screen prompt, and miss some shots. Cannon designers surely have their reasons, but still, this seems unnecessary- I have a smaller, older Canon with the flash fixed firmly in position for use any time.-With very close-up flash shots the lens barrel shadow gets in the picture, visible as a dark, circular area, which ruins the photo.  Back off a bit to permit the flash to clear the lens shadow.-Sharpness of extreme telephoto shots is soft, though as good as I expect from a point-and-shoot camera in this price range.Other Thoughts and Conclusions-I strongly recommend purchasing a case with any camera. Just laying it around, much less carrying it in the woods- will eventually scratch and pit the camera and the LCD.-Another recommendation is: read the manual. The manual will tell you how to use it, how to deal with problems, and how to use its many, many features. Some of the controls, such as the "control dial" and the "zoom lever," require a delicate touch and a bit of practice. Spend some time sitting around, exploring the camera with the manual. Then, when a bald eagle lands on your bird feeder, you will be ready!-I would like to be able to save images in formats other than JPG, such as TIFF or RAW.-I am a plant photographer; I purchased this camera as a "companion" for my big SLR, to shoot habitats and mid-range pictures. So far the drawbacks are minor or I have easily worked around them. I would buy it again, and I have recommended it and Amazon-dot-com to several friends.

Reviews.Title: It's ok
Reviews.Author: Bret Linford
Reviews.Content: We have owned this camera for over a year.Pros:Takes great outdoor photos. You can often times get a nice blurry background.gets rid of red-eyeCons:Takes poor indoor/low-light photos. Often blurry.Way too long flash re-set.Battery drainer.When recording video in low-light, its goes in and out of focusing.Sometimes the auto-flash does not go off when it definitely should and and 'auto' setting there is no way to force the flash on

Reviews.Title: Excels in close-up shots!!!
Reviews.Author: a6m5
Reviews.Content: Stepping up from a low-end Nikon camera, this Canon has been quite an upgrade for just a few dollars more.  Just the control you'll have over every little setting has been really great.Batteries - This camera will take two AA batteries.  Before purchasing the camera, I saw handful of reviews complaining about this camera draining batteries, but I honestly have no idea what they are talking about.  I wasn't counting, but the cheap AA batteries the camera came with probably gave me a 100 to 200 shots.  Some taken with flash.  Out of the four digital cameras I've owned, this in fact has been the most energy-efficient camera I've owned.  After using up the cheapie AA batteries, I now use the rechargeables, and they've been working out just perfectly.Picture/Close-up's - I am a horrid photographer.  With the Nikon Coolpix L12, I think I was pretty much the worst photographer in the world.  Nikon was bullet-proof however, and it is still 100% functional.  But the reason I started shopping for new camera was the close shots.  I tried take pictures for eBay, or of diecast cars, and Nikon Coolpix L12, like many other cameras were not equipped to take close-up shots.  Pictures all ended up being blurry, out of focus.  This Canon however, there has been times that I'm so close to the object, the lens accidentally tap what I'm trying to take a picture of.  You can get almost that close, and it still takes a detailed photo completely in focus.  This ability makes this Canon my favorite camera.I waited until I owned this camera for little bit before writing this review.  This is because I was bit worried about the latching design on the battery cover/door.  I did not like the way it released/unlatched/opened, and I was somewhat skeptical of its' durability.  I'm happy to report that battery cover, along with everything else has been rock-solid on this camera.  I've never owned a Canon before this, but I would not hesitate recommending one after my experience with this camera.I was originally going to give it four stars, because the pictures I take does not exactly come out professional quality, but thinking about it a bit more, that's more of the problem with the operator.  Pictures do come out pretty good, which means the camera is compensating a lot for lack of photography skills, or even basic knowledge on my part.  PowerShot SX130IS gets five stars from me.  Damn near perfect camera for the price.

Reviews.Title: perfect for me
Reviews.Author: javesmami
Reviews.Content: i absolutely love this camera! i have always had canons since the my 1st digital camera that my parents bought for me. this camera is no exception. it takes great pictures, is easy to use, and if u take the time to learn the ins & outs, has a lot of options and fun things to play around with. i bought this off of amazon (including a 3 yr warranty) for less than the cost of it on sale @ walmart that only had a 1 yr warranty. everyone compliments me on this camera, and when i tell them what i paid & that i'm worry free for the next 3 years, they just don't believe it. incredibly happy with this purchase!

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!
Reviews.Author: John Ergle
Reviews.Content: Just bought this camera, so I'm still on my first couple hundred photos, but I must say, so far I really like it!  We've been through quite a few point-and-shoot cameras, and this is a great camera for the price!  I just went through over a hundred photos, and I didn't think I had to edit color or contrast on a single one.  Indoor photos in low light weren't the greatest, but I haven't seen a point-and-shoot camera yet that does a good job with those.  Other reviews were pretty much on target about the battery life - it does go through batteries pretty quick.  I do like that it gives you a low-battery warning though.  A previous camera we had would just go dead when the battery was out.  Even after it started flashing the low-battery warning, I was able to take another 20 or so pics with this one.  We'll get some rechargeable batteries, and I think this will be a great camera!

Reviews.Title: Gr8 Cam, Gr8 Pix.
Reviews.Author: Russ
Reviews.Content: Pros: high quality images at 20x zoom, excellent image stabilization, excellent night captures, long battery life, good quality video.Cons: cost, no continous capture modeI am running short of words to describe: For past 10 years that I have used Canon cams, this happens to be the best I owned so far. Had the feel of a DSLR in a regular cam.

Reviews.Title: Low Battery Indicate on fresh NIMH cells
Reviews.Author: F. Lamaestra
Reviews.Content: I've had this unit for about 1 year, and have noticed that this unit will also start flashing low battery seemingly after only been in use for about 30 minutes, mostly idle, maybe after 100 shots and 10 minutes of video.I make sure to fully discharge and then charge my AA Sanyo NIMH 2700mah batteries using my Lacross charger. It takes longer to do this but it's worth it.Cannon does not have a firmeare fix for this issue, but I agree something needs to be reviewed. Google this issue and it will pop up in mutliple places.Luckly I carry many NIMH batteries to shows so I have plenty of juice. I just haute it when the camera shuts off in the middle of a 5 minute interview with seemly fresh batteries.

Reviews.Title: Amazing value
Reviews.Author: B "B"
Reviews.Content: Granted, you have to play with the settings but this camera delivers amazing photos for a non-SLR. Some photographer friends of mine with Canons to make you jealous were amazed by what I was able to capture in Yosemite, Zion and the Grand Canyon (which it turns out is very hard to do justice to in photos).My only complaint is that the flash, especially the filler flash for outdoor daylight photos, is a little too bright but I took the advice of another review and put a single layer of masking tape over it and it worked perfectly.Well worth it for a great point-and-shoot. Just make sure to get comfortable with the manual settings (P mode, I believe) because while the pre-sets are nice on the fly, the potential of this camera really came out when I played with aperture, etc. Amazing results.

Reviews.Title: very good
Reviews.Author: my score
Reviews.Content: I do not rate Items very often but this one stands up to the mfg. info. so good that I just had to give It a A+ easy to use and great picts. right out of the box.As for me. for the money It Is great.

Reviews.Title: No I am not a Professional
Reviews.Author: AndrewL
Reviews.Content: I am not a professional BUT this camera satisfies every desire I have.  I can take expert type pictures and with such clarity.  I am writing this from Lake Tittikaka, here in Bolivia.  With all the confidence in the world I can zoom in from a great distance and take a memorable shot as my eyes see it.  I have many times (with other cameras) have told people that the picture doesn't do the scenery justice.  Not with this.  The Canon PowerShot SX130IS does everything it says it can and to a high level of performance.If you are debating this camera for another. Go with this Canon, you won't be let down.  Most of all, it is very simple to use. Once in your hand it is very comfortable and the ability to program or use any of the menu's is easy.  My all time favorite feature is the timer.  Many times I get my wife in focus, just the right spot, and the 10 second timer is more than enough.  She showed me the custom feature of the custom settings and now we are trying to do some trick photography shots. I am so please with this purchase.  I would believe that this would exceed anyones expectations as a gift as well!

Reviews.Title: The Canon PowerShot SX130 IS is a rare gem!
Reviews.Author: Alli-O "Alli-O"
Reviews.Content: Wow, this is a fine camera.  Detail is remarkable.  Image stablization is very functional.  Set to "auto," it's the best point-and-shoot I've used from the Canon line (also the A480 and the SD850 IS).  The pluses add up with the ability to set aperture or shutter priorities, flash intensity, and ISO.The "Scene" selections actually enhance the photos.  I especially like the "Super Vivid" one that gives the pictures more color saturation.  It really brings recent pictures from the Western Carribean alive!  The flip-up flash is a little difficult to remember, and the flash recharge time is a little too long, but on the whole, that's blaming the camera for my absent-mindedness.I've seen complaints that the camera is too large, but the size is more than offset by the huge, bright, 3" screen.  The only thing I find missing is a viewfinder, because in bright sunlight, using any LCD screen is a crapshoot.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: MElias
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for photos and video. The pictures are clear and the video has great sound.  I love the larger screen on the back of the camera.  There is a flash that you can easily pull up when needed as well. The only downside is that the batteries don't last very long but we bought rechargeable batteries and they work great!

Reviews.Title: This is an excellent pocket camera. Very very easy to use. Takes excellant photos.
Reviews.Author: Jan
Reviews.Content: This is a very good camera. So easy to use. And even the owners manual is easy to use. I would recommend this camera for anyone wanting a smaller camera that takes good pictures and is easy to use. I love the Cannon products.

Reviews.Title: Great camera to hold me over until I get a DSLR
Reviews.Author: DiggzDaKaykes
Reviews.Content: I like the look of it, I like the size of it, I like the quality of the pictures, and I like the price of itBuy rechargeable batteries from amazon for like $10 and the battery issue people complained about is diminished greatlyUse manual mode and raise your shutter speed if you do not want blurry pictures [people complained about it]If you want something that is more advanced than a simple point and shoot this is a great camera, which you can have a lot of fun with!

Reviews.Title: Best Canon I've owned!
Reviews.Author: Lynda Lacy-Boltz
Reviews.Content: This camera replaced my (stolen) G9, and I'm happy to say I like it even a bit better than the G9.  It is quick, easy, and produces a high quality resolution that works well for me, as I am a graphic designer as well as photographer.  Colors and clear and true.  Great work, Canon!

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot
Reviews.Author: Book Happy "Mary"
Reviews.Content: Just to state right up front that I'm not a really great photographer. I bought the Canon PowerShot SX130IS for the optical zoom as my current Sony has only a 3x optical zoom.  Having fun with this camera.  No issues with the batteries ( I also purchased rechargable AA's since I know, in general how quickly cameras use regular alkaline batteries).  I'm happy with my choice and would recommend this to others.

Reviews.Title: SX130is upgrade
Reviews.Author: E. J. Deangeli
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera to replace my wifes 110is which has been a quality work horse for a person who averages 200 shots a week, yes 200. She is very happy with the new camera and its upgrades. It is much the same unit with a better lens and more resolution.I use two Canon high end SLR cameras and this 130 captures as good or better pictures in most all situations. Best camera for the price on todays market.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera.  Screen is Fuzzy.
Reviews.Author: Kris
Reviews.Content: Got this camera on a whim to replace my aging but still stable A75.  Awesome pictures.  Easy to learn and use.  But the main issue I have is the screen is fuzzy and pixelated when i go to take a picture, but after i snap it, the Pic is perfectly clear on the same screen.I dont understand why its so grainy when im taking a picture, but crystal clear when i view it.Dont hesitate to buy this though.  Its a very good camera for the price and has an awesome zoom.  Eats batteries for lunch though.  Definitely get rechargeable.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good
Reviews.Author: Amber Gibson
Reviews.Content: I've been using this camera for a few weeks now, and the one thing that I've noticed and have had to tweek things a little to fix is that pictures are often slightly blurred, as if the shutter speed isn't fast enough. Fortunately, I've been able to fix this by trying different settings (like low light, or under 'P' changing the lighting style that I am in and putting the flash on). I'm really impressed with all of the capabilities that it has, all of the settings, and different professionalish photography styles available. I was really stoked that it had a setting where all colors except one of your choosing are black and white. It made for some beautiful Christmas shots with the vivid reds.

Reviews.Title: Canon SX130 IS
Reviews.Author: Erzsi F.
Reviews.Content: Great camera, excelent features, you can use zoom with video with excelent focusing no distorsions, very good sound quality, excelent picture quality, love this camera. I just got it so I'm still learning all the features, but very easy to use for starters and good features for semi pro.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera for the price..
Reviews.Author: Wayne Kindred
Reviews.Content: If you take a lot of pictures using the flash, this may not be the camera for you.  But if most of your pictures are taken outdoors in good light, this camera will produce clear, sharp, vivid pictures.  It also produces very good video.  Another common complaint is battery life.  Alkaline batteries are totally useless, but I purchased a set of Rav O Vac Pre-Charged batteries and got more than 300 pictures before having to recharge them.  Overall, as a general purpose camera, with long zoom, this one is hard to beat for the price.
